bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Frederick F. Russell, October 27, 1927

div1.p: Kean expresses his continued interest in the status of yellow fever investigations, experimentation on monkeys, and Carter's book on the history of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Frederick F. Russell, October 27, 1927
div1.opener:
Per.file
27 October, 1927
General F. F. Russell, Director
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York.
My dear Russell:
div1.p:
I appreciate very much your nice letter of
October 25th and understand perfectly why the present is not
the time for reviewing the work on yellow fever. I feel
gratified that you have considered the matter so seriously, and
will put you down in my little black book for a review a year
from now, and will take it up with you then.

I do not know what the present status of Dr.
Henry R. Carter's book is; he was a very interesting man, and I
expect his book will be also.

If Rockefeller Foundation distributes reprints of
Mr. Lawrence H. Dunn's articles I would be glad to get them. All
this yellow fever work is of fascinating interest to me and I am
quite thrilled to that Beeuwkes has been able to produce yellow
fever in Asiatic monkeys. Agramonte failed in his effort to
do so, but I do not know what the variety of monkey was that
he used. I believe that monkeys from the yellow fever habitat
might be immune just as the indigenous human population was.
I note your warning that this information is confidential at
present.

It will be a great pleasure to see you when
you come down to the Museum the next time you are in Washington.
Perhaps we might go to lunch together.
With thanks, and best wishes, I am
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, J.R. KEAN
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retd.
Editor. JRK/B
